seg.seg: ... (not) in a place where the (wind) goes; not in a place where it rains;
... is to be brought ... ; not in a place where water is released; not ...
... it is (not) to be scoured (?) with sand and dung. It is not to be put on excrement (?).
... it is (not) to be put on ... too long. It is not to be broken intentionally.
.. it is (not) to be ... It is to be guarded carefully. • You are not to seek another alms bowl yourself.
... if you have ..., it is to be given up in the community. This ...
/// – aleccemeṃ ñare sarki yāṣträ duṣkṛta alecce
/// -ṣṣä(ṃ) jñātikeṃ wāpatsi watkäṣṣäṃ|watkaṣäṃ, [he has] no offence.

p.note: The spelling llya for the nom.sg.f. ending of the gerund for usual lya is striking, but need to reflect anything in real speech. Should it stand for some speech-real phenomenon, then it would obviously be a palatalisated geminate /ĺĺ/.

Upper, lower, and right margins preserved. Pace 93, 84 is probably right that the string hole space is preserved in lines a4 and b3, and probably also in a3 and b4. Thus the leaf may have been relatively small, i.e. not wider than approximately 15 cms.
84 describes the ms as "[w]ritten in medium ductus, and clearly preserved, but the manuscript is blackened both sides, worse on the verso".
īkene: the first akṣara is probably to be read as ī, not i (pace 84; 93).

(ma wara)ñcäcce meltesa käccillya: the restoration of this clause is difficult. Following 84, 89 and 113, 333-334 restores (śi)ñcäcce meltesa käccillya and translates "/// it should not be put down on the on snow-covered dung.". This expression is not found in the Chinese parallel that he adduces. However, he underlines "You should not wash it with the sand and the dung.", his translation of 不應以雜沙牛屎洗。, meaning that this passage is also found in the Tocharian B text (cf also 113 "Der Mönch [...] muß ermahnt werden, [...] sie nicht mit Sand oder Kuhurin zu reinigen"). As far as I can see, it is not necessary to restore /// ñcäcce as (śi)ñcäcce: many more words in -ñce could form an adjective in -tstse. One of these is warañce 'sand', which seems to fit the context better: 以雜沙牛屎 'with a mix of sand and cow dung' may have been warañcäcce meltesa, literally 'with sandy cow dung', in Tocharian B. The next problem is the verb kətt- or kətk-, traditionally 'put down' (113; 159), but in fact the passages hardly allow us to establish its meaning. On the basis of the passage under discussion, one would rather expect something like 'wash, scour', which fits käccīyeṃ-ne b5 perfectly: 'Two (hell guards) scoured his body with gravel'. käccītär b5 is more difficult to interpret. It is clearly a bad wish to an honourable person by a jealous person. Perhaps 'he should be scoured together with this or that one' is also a possibility there.
s·: pace 93, who reads ·[s]·, the s is not uncertain and it is not lowered.

läntsa: for this hapax legomenon, 335 plausibly suggests the meaning 'excrement', based on the assumption that the word is borrowed from Skt. laṇḍa 'excrement'. A minor point is that we would rather expect lānt, i.e. /lant/, not /lənt/.
mäkte: seems to stand for makte 'self', not for mäkte 'how, so' (pace 89; not translated by 334).
rī(talle): 335 restores rī(tatar), which is grammatically also possible.
/// -māne yayāṣṣoṣ: some of these akṣaras are damaged, but the reading is certain, pace 184, who reads /// (ṣa)[mān]e ya[yā]ṣṣoṣ (followed by 93).
93 reads the first damaged akṣara as [60].
yāṣt_r_a: this is the correct reading (№7), pace 84, who reads yaṣt_r_a (followed by 93).

a1, a2. īkene: the first akṣara is probably to be read as ī, not i (pace [[Broomhead I]]: 84; [[Ogihara 2009]]: 93).

a3. (ma wara)ñcäcce meltesa käccillya: the restoration of this clause is difficult. Following [[Broomhead I]]: 84, 89 and [[Hilmarsson 1996]]: 113, [[Ogihara 2009]]: 333-334 restores (śi)ñcäcce meltesa käccillya and translates "/// it should not be put down on the on snow-covered dung.". This expression is not found in the Chinese parallel that he adduces. However, he underlines "You should not wash it with the sand and the dung.", his translation of 不應以雜沙牛屎洗。, meaning that this passage is also found in the Tocharian B text (cf also [[Rosen 1959]]: 113 "Der Mönch [...] muß ermahnt werden, [...] sie nicht mit Sand oder Kuhurin zu reinigen"). As far as I can see, it is not necessary to restore /// ñcäcce as (śi)ñcäcce: many more words in -ñce could form an adjective in -tstse. One of these is warañce 'sand', which seems to fit the context better: 以雜沙牛屎 'with a mix of sand and cow dung' may have been warañcäcce meltesa, literally 'with sandy cow dung', in Tocharian B. The next problem is the verb kətt- or kətk-, traditionally 'put down' ([[Hilmarsson 1996]]: 113; [[Adams, DoT]]: 159), but in fact the passages hardly allow us to establish its meaning. On the basis of the passage under discussion, one would rather expect something like 'wash, scour', which fits käccīyeṃ-ne [[THT 22]] b5 perfectly: 'Two (hell guards) scoured his body with gravel'. käccītär [[THT 33]] b5 is more difficult to interpret. It is clearly a bad wish to an honourable person by a jealous person. Perhaps 'he should be scoured together with this or that one' is also a possibility there.

a4. s·: pace [[Ogihara 2009]]: 93, who reads ·[s]·, the s is not uncertain and it is not lowered.

a5. läntsa: for this hapax legomenon, [[Ogihara 2009]]: 335 plausibly suggests the meaning 'excrement', based on the assumption that the word is borrowed from Skt. laṇḍa 'excrement'. A minor point is that we would rather expect lānt, i.e. /lant/, not /lənt/.

a5. mäkte: seems to stand for makte 'self', not for mäkte 'how, so' (pace [[Broomhead I]]: 89; not translated by [[Ogihara 2009]]: 334).

a5. rī(talle): [[Ogihara 2009]]: 335 restores rī(tatar), which is grammatically also possible.

a6. tākañca: for tākañc, i.e. tākaṃ-c.

b1. /// -māne yayāṣṣoṣ: some of these akṣaras are damaged, but the reading is certain, pace [[Broomhead I]]: 184, who reads /// (ṣa)[mān]e ya[yā]ṣṣoṣ (followed by [[Ogihara 2009]]: 93).

b2. [[Ogihara 2009]]: 93 reads the first damaged akṣara as [60].

b2. yāṣt_r_a: this is the correct reading ([[Peyrot 2007]]: №7), pace [[Broomhead I]]: 84, who reads yaṣt_r_a (followed by [[Ogihara 2009]]: 93).

b6. watka: a mistake for watkäṣṣäṃ ([[Thomas 1954]]: 727).

[[Broomhead I]]: 89 translates:

a1 In a place not accessible to the wind [and] a place not accessible to the rain.

a2 ... is to be carried. In a place where water cannot penetrate ...

a3 [The vessel] is not to be placed on śiñcäcce dung ... [and] is not to be placed on a läṃ (?).

a4 ... is to be placed for a long time, [and] without the intention of striking it.

a5 [is] to be ...: [It is] to be guarded carefully [so that] no strange vessel ...

a6 If there should be ... for you. [it is] to be given back to the community.

b1 Whichever monk [has] a thread [he has] begged. If he should

b2 ask a stranger to weave [it for him] [then there is ...] And if he should beg a thread from a stranger [then] [there is] du. [If he should order] a stranger

b3 [then there is] a niḥsargika pātayantikā. 70. If he should beg a thread from relatives

b4 [then there is] no crime. [But] should he order a stranger to weave [the thread] [then he commits] niḥsargika.

b5 [Whosoever] orders a thread to be woven by relatives [commits] no crime.

b6 [So] if he should order a relative to weave [it for him] [then he is] without crime.

It is to be guarded carefully. • You are not to seek another alms bowl yourself. a6 ... if you have ..., it is to be given up in the community. This ... b1 /// (ṣa)māne yayāṣṣoṣ ñare sarki • alecce wāpa b2 /// – aleccemeṃ ñare sarki yāṣträ duṣkṛta alecce b3 /// (wa)t(kä)ṣṣäṃ niḥsargika-pātayantika 70 jñātikenmeṃ ñare sarki b4 /// (ma trä)ṅko alecce wāpatsi watkäṣṣäṃ niḥsargika-pātayantika b5 /// -ṣṣä(ṃ) jñātikeṃ wāpatsi watkäṣṣäṃ|watkaṣäṃ, [he has] no offence. b6 /// (jñā)tikeṃ wāpatsi watkäṣṣäṃ|watka, [he is] without offence. ||
